titleStmt.title: Letter from Marie Flavell to Thomas Hardy — 6 March 1925

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished autograph letter held at the Dorset History Centre / Dorset Museum, MS H.2410.

physDesc.p: Two-leaf note-paper (4 pages including blanks), smooth cream wove paper; written in blue ink in a neat, right-slanting cursive hand. Single horizontal fold; light show-through.

msDesc.note: Right‑hand heading in manuscript gives school address: “Girls’ High School, Lytham Rd., Blackpool.”

Pencilled editorial note beneath signature: ‘in “A Pair of Blue Eyes”; The “Cliff without a name,” so far as it is anywhere, is near Beeny, about a mile from Boscastle. See Mr Hardy’s “Collected Poems,” 1 vol. (Macmillan & Co., publishers). — See!’
Single hand throughout; blue ink; steady rounded letterforms with long descenders; likely steel nib fountain pen.

abstract.p: Writing from the Girls’ High School, Blackpool, Marie Flavell asks Thomas Hardy to identify the location of the “Cliff without a name,” noting its appearance on maps and a recollection of a reference in Tess of the d’Urbervilles; an editorial pencil note associates the spot with Beeny near Boscastle.

note.p: Marie Flavell (unidentified in VIAF) writes from the Girls’ High School, Blackpool, requesting topographical clarification from novelist and poet Thomas Hardy. The enquiry references Hardy’s Cornwall settings; the pencilled editorial note connects the query with scenes from A Pair of Blue Eyes and points to a location near Beeny and Boscastle.

opener.dateline:
Girls’ High School, Lytham Rd., Blackpool.
6–3–25.

body.p:
I’m very sorry to trouble you, but I have been wondering whether you can tell me where the “Cliff without a name” is.
It appears on the maps, and as far as I remember it is mentioned in Tess of the D’Urbervilles.
I am very interested in it as I live in Bude, and know that particular part of the coast fairly well.
